raw_text:
Campbell returns to election team
 
 Ex-Downing Street media chief Alastair Campbell will return to the fold to strengthen Labour's general election campaign, the party has confirmed.
 
 Mr Campbell has consistently made public his keenness to play a part in the poll, expected in May. Both Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell and Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott have welcomed his return. "He is a strong Labour Party member," Mr Prescott told BBC One's Breakfast With Frost programme.
 
 Mr Campbell quit Number 10 in August 2003 after being Tony Blair's right-hand man at the 1997 and 2001 elections. Labour have refused to discuss his exact new position and have not said how it would affect his Downing Street replacement David Hill. "Of course Alastair's going to be part of the election campaign and I think that all of us who will also be part of the election campaign are very pleased about that," Ms Jowell told Sky News.
 
 But she said his return would not put anybody else's "nose out of joint". "This is the daft thing about the way in which politics is written about," Ms Jowell added. "There's room for everybody. We serve the country better if we make room for all the talent." A Labour source told the Sunday Times Mr Campbell would "effectively front" the election media campaign but said he would be given no formal title.
 
 Labour strategists told the paper he would be "set loose" on Conservative leader Michael Howard in attacking his party's economic record when it was in power. "They used pictures from the 1970s in the 1992 campaign to remind people of the winter of discontent - and now it's our turn," the source told the paper. "Making Michael Howard leader gives us an unmissable opportunity to remind people what it was like to pay mortgage rates of 15% even if it was more than a decade ago." Mr Campbell was at the centre of the government's row with BBC over Andrew Gilligan's story about the Iraq weapons dossier. The Hutton inquiry cleared him of "sexing up" the dossier in the run-up to the Iraq war. Since leaving Downing Street, he has toured the country with his one man show, An Audience With Alastair Campbell and presented a number of interview programmes for Channel 4.
llama3.2:1b: Alastair Campbell will return to Labour's general election campaign after quitting Number 10 in August 2003. Both Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell and Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott have welcomed his return, saying he is a strong Labour Party member. Campbell will "effectively front" the media campaign but will not be given a formal title. He plans to attack Michael Howard's economic record when it was in power.
llama3.2:3b: Alastair Campbell will return to Labour's general election campaign after quitting as Tony Blair's right-hand man in 2003. Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott and Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell have welcomed his return. Campbell will "effectively front" the media campaign, but will not be given a formal title. He is expected to target Conservative leader Michael Howard on his party's economic record.
gemma2:2b: Alastair Campbell is returning to Labour's general election campaign. He will play a key role in the media strategy but does not have a formal title. He plans to focus on attacking Conservative leader Michael Howard's economic record, drawing comparisons to the "winter of discontent."  Campbell previously served as Tony Blair’s right-hand man during past elections.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Alastair Campbell will return to the general election team after quitting Number 10 in August 2003. He returned following a decision that Labour would be given no formal title, but that his return would not put anybody else's "nose out of joint." His presence on the election campaign media campaign will likely make him an important candidate for both parties and help to make the general election more accessible.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ex-Downing Street media chief Alastair Campbell returns to Labour's election team, expected in May. Both Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell and Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott welcome his return, despite no official position being confirmed. The new post is not expected to affect David Hill's replacement role. Campbell will play a significant part in the campaign but won't have a formal title. His previous work against Margaret Thatcher during her run for prime minister will likely be used against Conservative leader Michael Howard if elected.
qwen2.5:3b: Alastair Campbell, former Downing Street media chief, is returning to Labour's general election campaign in May. Both Culture Secretary Tessa Jowell and Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott have welcomed his return. Labour has not disclosed Campbell's exact role but he will reportedly lead the election media campaign. The party believes there is room for all talent. Prior to his time at Number 10, Campbell was involved in a row with BBC over Andrew Gilligan’s Iraq dossier story and cleared of "sexing up" the dossier by the Hutton inquiry. He has also performed as part of an audience show and presented interviews on Channel 4 since leaving Downing Street.
opencoder:1.5b:
Campbell returns to election team.

Alastair Campbell will return to the fold to strengthen Labour's general election campaign.

Mr Campbell has consistently made public his keenness to play a part in the poll, expected in May.

Tessa Jowell and John Prescott have welcomed his return.

"He is a strong Labour Party member," Mr Prescott told BBC One's Breakfast With Frost programme.

Tony Blair's right-hand man in Number 10 in August 2003 after being David Hill's Downing Street replacement. "Of course Alastair's going to be part of the election campaign and I think that all of us who will also be part of the election campaign are very pleased about that," Tessa said.

Ms Jowell told Sky News. But she said his return would not put anybody else's "nose out of joint". 

"Room for everybody is there, we serve the country better if we make room for all the talent."

A Labour source explained Mr Campbell would "effectively front" the election media campaign but said he would be given no formal title.

Labour strategists told the paper he would be set loose on Conservative leader Michael Howard in attacking his party's economic record when it was in power. The BBC and Sunday Times reported a similar move.
smollm:1.7b: Campbell returns to election team after exiting Downing Street media role
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to help summarize this text about Alastair Campbell's return to the Labour Party. Let me read through it carefully.

First, it says Campbell is returning to the election team. That makes sense because he was previously a media chief. He's been there since August 2003 when he took over at Number 10 after Tony Blair, who was his right-hand man for both the 1997 and 2001 elections. Now, his new role is in the general election campaign in May.

The party has welcomed him, mentioning that he's a strong Labour member and looking forward to his presence. Both Tessa Jowell and John Prescott have praised him on BBC One. He was expected in May, so it's likely near the election time.

But there are some nuances too. The media team is focused on building Campbell into an election worker, which is good for the campaign. However, they're concerned that his return might cause others to feel "nose out of joint," meaning they might compete more than intended. Jowell mentioned that this could be a daft thing about politics being written about too much.

Another point is regarding the replacement of David Hill with Mr. Campbell. A Labour source said he would effectively front the campaign but wouldn't take any formal title. So his role isn't official yet, which gives the party time to develop him as an individual.

There are also discussions between strategists and the Sunday Times about how they might use older content from the 1970s against Michael Howard's new leadership. They want to remind people about past discontent but now focus on recent issues affecting rates.

Finally, there was a controversy over a BBC story about Iraq weapons. The Hutton inquiry cleared him of "sexing up" the evidence, which is about using controversial material as part of media coverage. He has done interviews and shown his show An Audience With Alastair Campbell for Channel 4.

So putting this all together, I need to condense these points into a concise summary without any explanations or formatting. It should be plain text, just the key ideas: Campbell's return, his role in election campaign, concerns about others competing too much, his potential status as campaign worker but not yet official, media discussions with strategists about past content and future issues, and a mention of his involvement with a UK TV show.
</think>

Alastair Campbell returns to Labour after taking over as media chief following Tony Blair's tenure. He is expected in the general election campaign in May and will serve as an elected candidate for London’s local election. The party has praised his strong Labour credentials and concerns about others competing too much, fearing a daft political writing style. Campbell's role isn't official yet but aims to front the campaign. Media discussions with strategists involve using old 1970s content against Michael Howard, aiming to remind people of past discontent while focusing on recent issues like mortgage rates. He is also involved in a UK TV show.
tinyllama:1.1b: Campbell, who served as Chief Strategist at Number 10 during Tony Blair's first term in office, will return to the Labour Party's general election campaign after being announced as the new Director of Public Procurement for the party. Despite having previous political experience and serving under the former prime minister, Campbell is not expected to take on a formal title within the party. Instead, he will be given no official role or responsibility aside from his current position as an influential member of Labour's campaign team. The party has not explicitly announced how his return would affect their election strategy, and it remains unclear how he will be used in the media campaign against the Conservative Party's leader, Michael Howard.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
User: Is it true that Alastair Campbell has returned to the Labour Party as their new campaign manager? 

 Developer: Yes, it is true. He will be leading their election campaign in May. The details about his return and his duties are not available yet, but we can assume he will be playing a key role in helping Labour win back its popular vote.

He was previously Tony Blair's chief of staff and has expressed interest in re-joining the team since August 2003. Both Tessa Jowell and John Prescott have welcomed his return. Mr Campbell's specific role is not yet known, but he will likely focus on attacking Conservative leader Michael Howard's economic record when it was Labour's government that was in power.

hermes3:3b: Alastair Campbell returns to Labour's general election campaign team.

His new role will likely involve fronting the party's media campaign, criticizing the Conservative Party's economic record during their previous tenure, and referencing high mortgage rates of 15%. Labour strategists plan to use historical context from the 1970s winter of discontent to illustrate the impact on voters. Campbell, after resigning in August 2003 following Tony Blair's tenure, has been promoting his one-man show and hosting interview programs for Channel 4 since leaving Downing Street. His return is seen as an opportunity to strengthen Labour's campaign, not as a threat to others' roles within the party.
